--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Reuben Grinberg <reuben.grinberg@y...> 
wrote:
> Hello,
> 
> I just ported the Single pole balancing code from the C++ version 
to 
> JNeat.
> 
> I'm using the pole1startgenes from the C++ version and the 
parameters 
> I'm using are in p2test.ne
> 
> So far I've evolved for 123 generations (pop = 1000) and the 
fitness is 
> only at 602 (that is, the pole stays up for 602 time steps).
> 
> This seems strange because Ken's thesis says he was able to do 
double 
> pole balancing in 24 generations. Hmm...
> 
> Do any of you know if the activate function in the JNeat version 
is 
> different than activate in Ken's C++ version? In some places in 
the 
> JNeat version, activate is called for 1+networkDepth times. Does 
> activate in Ken's version propagate new vals all the way from 
input to 
> output?
> 

The activation should be the same, but you should check to make sure 
that the sigmoid in mine (fsigmoid) and JNEAT are the same.  But the 
way activation works should be that a single activation causes the 
signal to travel only the length of a single connection.  The reason 
JNEAT activates 1+networkDepth times is that it is doing 
classification problems.  For continuous control problems, it 
usually is only activated once per timestep.

You may want to check that you have the right genome file for single 
pole balancing.  It does sound like something is wrong if you are 
getting stuck on such an easy problem.

ken
